questions.text: In which state was Duncan born?
questions.explanation:
New Jersey.

	Duncan was born in 1969 in Montclair, New Jersey. He split his time between there and his grandma's house in the Carolinas.

questions.text: Duncan is heavily involved in Buddhism.
questions.explanation:
True.

	Duncan is a Buddhist and wrote the foreword to a book that applied Buddhist principles to everyday life by Soka Gakkai leader Daisaku Ikeda.

questions.text: What was Duncan's second album called?
questions.explanation:
Humming.

	"Humming" was released in 1998, featuring the London Session Orchestra on some tracks. After the last song "Nichiren", there is a secret track called "Foreshadowing".

questions.text: With whom did Duncan collaborate to make his third album: "Phantom Moon"?
questions.explanation:
Steven Sater.

	Sheik and Sater later teamed up to write the musical "Spring Awakening", which debuted on Broadway in 2006. They met through their mutual interest in Buddhism.

questions.text: Which album is Duncan's single "Half-Life" from?
questions.explanation:
Daylight.

	"Half-Life" is one of Duncan's hit singles, along with "Barely Breathing" and "On A High".

questions.text: For which film did Sheik write the music?
questions.correct: A Home At The End Of The World
questions.explanation:
A Home At The End Of The World.

	"A Home At The End Of The World" was released in 2004, with two songs contributed by Duncan. It starred Robin Wright Penn and Colin Farrell.

questions.text: "White Limousine" featured a DVD-ROM that allowed people to remix tracks from the album.
questions.explanation:
True.

	Fans can show off their remixes at www.limoremix.com

questions.text: How many previously unreleased tracks were featured on 2006's "Brighter/Later"?
questions.explanation:
Three.

	A live version of "Home", a remix of "For You" and a song called "Court and Spark" were the three tracks that were previously unreleased.

options: A Home at the End of the World
questions.explanation:
What a Girl Wants.

	"What a Girl Wants" is a teenage comedy starring Amanda Bynes. It was released in 2003 and also starred Colin Firth as her father.

questions.text: Are these the right lyrics from "On a High"?: "You are fine, you are fine/There's nothing worth fearing/'Cause there never will be no conspiracy of sadness."
questions.explanation:
No.

	The correct lyrics are: "You are fine, you are fine/There's nothing worth fearing/'Cause there never will be no conspiracy of happiness."
